principal_desk.title: From the Principal's Desk
principal_desk.author: Dr. Gunmeet Bindra
principal_desk.content:
The Lion King, as a Disney animated film, not only entertained an audience, but also shared wisdom about real-life experiences.

In their conversation, Simba curiously looks into the sky and says, "Looks like the winds are changing."

Rafiki responds, "Ahh, change is good."

This is a line that resonates deeply with me: "Change is good." In the realm of education, this statement holds tremendous significance. When we embrace change, we become catalysts for growth, not just in the lives of our students but also within ourselves. Having served just over a year in this esteemed, vintage legacy day-cum boarding school as its pioneering female Principal, in all humility, I am conscious of the responsibility that this change brings in.

The sheer manifestation of life lies solely in its inherent growth, and the active involvement of our students in a diverse range of sporting, cultural, and literary pursuits and bringing home accolades serve as an undeniable testament to their progressive development over time.

We are currently engaging with Generation Alpha and Generation Z, cohorts that possess an innate familiarity with the cloud, social media, and mobile technology due to having grown up with these innovations. They’ve known and adapted to these since birth – are also open to more technology, more changes, more adaptations. With the necessary knowledge and expertise, I reckon, they will be empowered to generate value that extends beyond their own generation, benefiting future generations as well.

Our genuine self-awareness flourishes when we forge meaningful connections with others. One pivotal way for me to foster this connection with the children is through the morning assembly, which provides an optimal opportunity for me to cultivate a bond with them and where I consistently emphasize the significance of pockets of time and the multitude of benefits they offer. By making the most of these interstices, we can optimize our efficiency and achieve meaningful outcomes.

Breathing new life into the school's cherished heritage, a current atmosphere of fervour and eagerness permeates the air. The school is consistently abuzz with a vibrant energy that pervades every aspect of learning, co-curricular endeavours, and beyond.

"Skill is the foundation upon which talent builds its masterpiece." Driven by continuous efforts to enhance and refine their skills, students venture into uncharted territories and unleash their untapped aptitude.

The world has changed and so have we. Drawing upon over 150 years of rich experience, we hold our traditions in high regard. However, we recognize the utmost significance of adapting to the ever- evolving world around us.

As I come to a close, let us embrace the power of "now." Each moment presents a chance for us to make a positive impact and create lasting change. Let us embark on this exciting journey, let us seize the present moment and make the most of it. C'est la vie!

God bless!
Dr. Gunmeet Bindra

academics.summary: Academic Results for 2014 have been excellent. Class 10 and Class 12 results reflect very strong performance across subjects.
academics.class_12_overview: Class 12 results were even better than the previous year: 136 students have got a distinction in all subjects.

round_square.description: Round Square is the core of Internationalism at DC. Students and teachers benefit from multiple global platforms.
highlights: More than 150 students have participated in Model United Nations programmes in the last two years in India and abroad.
Round Square International Conference hosted in 2007 at DC.
Seen as one of the best Indian schools to partner for internationalism.
6 students attended Annual Round Square International Conference in Florida.
Around 60 students attended South Asia & Gulf Regional Round Square Conferences in 2013.

g20_and_gales.g20: The G-20 group of Iconic Heads from prestigious schools across the world attended the G-20 conference in February 2013 at DC.
g20_and_gales.gales: GALES (Global Alliance of Leading-Edge Schools), with partners from 25+ countries, has only one Indian partner – DC. Its bi-annual summit venue was shifted from Raffles Institution, Singapore to DC, Indore in October 2014.

afs_and_exchanges.joint_study: A joint US, Australia & UK study of 10 schools in 10 countries on adapting to globalisation selected DC as the only Indian school.
afs_and_exchanges.teacher_training: Postgraduate teacher trainees from Melbourne School of Education, Australia visit DC annually for their practical stint.
afs_and_exchanges.indian_culture_course: A three-week course on Indian Culture run by DC attracts students, especially from Canada.

afs_detailed.afs_russian_group_visit: 11 students and 2 teachers from Russia visited for a fortnight.

leadership_and_summits: Senior Vice Principal attended Deputy Heads G-20 Conference at Wellington, Eton & Marlborough in the UK.
Senior Vice Principal and students attended the swearing-in ceremony of President Obama as part of a Leadership Conference in Washington.
Two students and a teacher attended the 'Ideas to Change the World' Summit at Raffles, Singapore.
10 students and a teacher attended a 10-day conference at Stanford University.

campus_overview.title: Campus Daly College
campus_overview.location_description: The Daly College is situated on a sprawling 118.8 acre lush green campus with manicured lawns, colourful gardens and two beautiful artificial lakes. This land was donated by the Holkar rulers of Indore.

natural_features.general_description: Lush green campus with landscaped lawns, flowering gardens and serene water bodies that create a peaceful learning environment.

sports_area.description: There are a large number of playing fields and courts in an area of 282,992.5 sq. meters in addition to heritage as well as modern buildings.

architecture.heritage_status: The main building of Daly College is one of the best examples of Indo-Saracenic architecture and is a symbol of the school’s rich legacy.
architecture.synthesis_of_styles: The main building is fundamentally a synthesis of Western and Indian architectural elements.

durbar_hall.description: The Durbar Hall is situated in the center of the main building and is one of the most iconic spaces on campus.
features: Houses portraits of some of the Original Donors
Includes the portrait of Gen. Sir Henry Daly

institutional_journey.history_summary: The Daly College has journeyed and evolved since 1870, growing from a residency for the Princes of Central India into a leading co-educational day-cum-boarding school.

ipsc_membership.description: Daly College came together with a few other institutions and started the Indian Public Schools’ Conference (IPSC), playing a pioneering role in the Indian public school movement.

round_square_membership.description: In 2005, Daly College became a proud member of Round Square, strengthening its focus on internationalism, leadership, service and holistic education.

education_world_2010.description: In 2010, Daly College was certified and ranked first in Infrastructure, Internationalism and Sports Education amongst the top boarding schools in India by the Education World – C fore survey.

recent_education_world_rankings.description: Daly College has been ranked first Day-Cum-Boarding school in Indore and Madhya Pradesh and second in India by Education World – C fore in recent rankings.

admissions_and_ethos.admissions_policy: Admissions are offered strictly on merit, regardless of caste or creed.
admissions_and_ethos.values_description: The school has grown in strength and reputation, upholding inclusivity, diversity and meritocracy as core values.
admissions_and_ethos.education_philosophy: Daly College offers the most modern education in a heritage setting, blending contemporary pedagogy with a strong sense of tradition and character-building.

campus_overview.summary_paragraph: The Daly College is situated on a sprawling 118.8 acre lush green campus with manicured lawns, colourful gardens and two beautiful artificial lakes. This land was donated by the Holkar rulers of Indore. There are a large number of playing fields & courts in an area of 282,992.5 sq. meters in addition to heritage as well as modern buildings. The main building of Daly College is amongst the best examples of the Indo-Saracenic style of architecture (designed by the architect, Col. Sir Swinton Jacob), and is essentially the pride of the Daly College. The main building at Daly College is fundamentally a synthesis of western and Indian elements. The Durbar Hall is situated in the center of the main building and houses the portraits of some of the Original Donors and of Gen. Sir Henry Daly. The Daly College has journeyed and evolved since 1870. It came together with a few other institutions and started the Indian Public School Conference (IPSC). In 2005, it became a proud member of Round Square. In 2010, it was certified and ranked first in Infrastructure, Internationalism and Sports Education amongst the top boarding schools in India by Education World – C fore, which is India’s Most Respected Schools’ Survey. Daly College has again been ranked as first Day-Cum-Boarding in Indore and Madhya Pradesh and second in India by Education World – C fore recently. The admissions are offered on merit, regardless of caste or creed. It has grown in strength and reputation and offers the most modern education in a heritage setting.

facility_entries.title: Temple
facility_entries.short_description: Heritage temple in Malwa style with Radha-Krishna idol, bells, Tulsi and Peepal tree.
facility_entries.content:
The college temple was built by the Indore Durbar and was funded by His Highness Charkhari. His Highness the Maharaja of Udaipur gave the "Murtis" for the temples. It was opened on 28th August 1910.

Temple means 'House of Gods', as the name suggests the place of silence, prayer and meditation. The temple of DC was built in the Malwa style. The beautiful idol of Radha-Krishna overwhelms the eye.

Along with the idol, the temple has metallic bells hanging from the ceiling. The infrastructure is like that of an ordinary temple, with a pointed peak. The steps give way to the entrance and running along the edges is a narrow path. It has a Tulsi plant along with a shady Peepal tree. The temple has lovely tiles with painted poses of Lord Ganesh. Alongside, there is another small exquisite temple of Lord Shiva.

The temple is open everyday in the morning as well as in the evening. On festivals and special occasions, service is organized in the temple.

facility_entries.title: Mosque
facility_entries.short_description: College mosque built by the Begum of Bhopal, a beautiful landmark for daily and Friday prayers.
facility_entries.content:
The College Mosque was built by Her Highness the Begum of Bhopal and was opened on 19 December 1910.

The College Mosque is one of the most beautiful buildings in our school campus.

It is located in the northern side of the campus and faces the west. It is very beautifully designed with very good interiors. The top of the Mosque has four big domes, which are like the four minars of the Mosque. As you enter the Mosque, you will come across an open passage way and then enter into a big hall where you can see many wall hangings which depict the pictures of the holy places like Mecca and Madina.

There are also a few small rooms, which are used by the people who come to the Mosque to get ready for a prayer, which is called Namaz. Every day Muslim students and teachers come to the Mosque to perform the holy prayers. On every Friday, almost the entire Muslim community of the campus assembles at the Mosque to do the special prayer.

facility_entries.title: Mess and Dining Halls
facility_entries.short_description: Separate senior and junior dining halls with carefully planned, nutritious menu and separate non-veg kitchen.
facility_entries.content:
The menu is planned with care to ensure that the food is nutritious and balanced. Non-vegetarian food is prepared separately in the kitchen.

There are two dining halls: one for the senior students and another for the juniors. The students' Mess Committee influences menu planning.

A new state-of-the-art kitchen is being planned with modern equipment according to the required/international standards.

facility_entries.title: Craft Technology Design Center
facility_entries.short_description: State-of-the-art hobby centre for visual and performing arts, nurturing creative talent.
facility_entries.content: A state of the art hobby centre which caters to the creative talent of the students. It has spacious and aesthetic facilities for Fine Arts, Sculpture, Pottery, Woodcraft, Photography, Textile Designing amongst visual arts and Music, Dance, Band and Dramatics amongst performing arts.

facility_entries.title: Laboratories
facility_entries.short_description: Full-fledged laboratories for sciences, technology, geography, mathematics and languages.
facility_entries.content: The school has full fledged laboratories for Physics, Chemistry, Biology, BioTech, C++, WebTech, IP, Geography, Maths and Language.

facility_entries.title: Auditorium
facility_entries.short_description: Air-conditioned 1200-seat auditorium used for assemblies, competitions and major functions.
facility_entries.content: An airconditioned auditorium, with a capacity to accommodate 1200 people is one of the crowning glories of the school. Here the students make use of their creative abilities and various competitions and functions are organized from time to time. Assembly is held here on a daily basis.

facility_entries.title: Hospital / Infirmary
facility_entries.short_description: 24x7 infirmary operating for over 88 years, headed by a paediatrician with visiting specialists.
facility_entries.content:
Our Daly College Infirmary has been operative from 88 years; now the same is presently headed by paediatrician Dr. Ankur Roy with a team of four nurses and operates 24x7.

All kinds of minor illness, trauma and cut injuries are dealt with utmost precision at the infirmary itself. We also have a visiting dentist, Dr. Atul Jajoo (MDS Orthodontist), and physiotherapists Dr. Jyoti and Dr. Mansi who visit on a daily basis.

facility_entries.title: Durbar Hall
facility_entries.short_description: Majestic central hall housing portraits of original donors and Gen. Sir Henry Daly; venue for dignitaries and key events.
facility_entries.content:
The Durbar Hall is situated in the centre of the main building and houses the portraits of some of the Original Donors and of Gen. Sir Henry Daly.

This is the most majestic facility of Daly College, where all dignitaries are welcomed and important meetings and events are held.

facility_entries.title: Sports Facilities
facility_entries.short_description: World-class sports infrastructure including cricket, tennis, swimming, hockey, football, shooting, squash, skating, climbing, fitness and horse riding.
facility_entries.overview: DC has world class facilities for sports namely, two cricket grounds which have hosted Ranji Trophy matches, Floodlit Deco Turf Tennis Courts, Olympic size Swimming pool, Floodlit synthetic surface Basketball Courts, Four Soccer fields, three Hockey grounds, independent athletic track and ground, an international class indoor completely air-conditioned Shooting range and nine glass backed squash courts, a 150 m floodlit Skating rink, six Sports Pavilions, Sports climbing wall, an Obstacle Course, a fitness centre and a modern centre for Badminton. The newest is the Horse riding facility.

daly_college_main_building.title: Daly College Main Building
daly_college_main_building.description: The construction of the main building was started in 1882 and opened by Lord Dufferin in 1885. It was entirely made of reinforced concrete.

usage.upper_floor: Classes were held on the upper floor.
usage.lower_floor: Contained the Principal's office, a general reading room for the Kumars and staff, and a library with numerous valuable books on Arts, Science, History, and Oriental Literature.

bust_of_sir_henry_daly.location: Central Hall on the upper floor
bust_of_sir_henry_daly.donor: H.H. Maharaja Madhavrao Scindia of Gwalior
bust_of_sir_henry_daly.description: The bust of General Sir Henry Daly was erected by H.H. Maharaja Madhavrao Scindia of Gwalior.

daly_college_main_building.later_history: When the college moved to its present premises in 1909, the building with the boarding houses was handed over to the Medical School.

principals_bungalow.title: The Principal's Bungalow
principals_bungalow.funding: Built out of money subscribed to the Mayo Memorial Fund.
principals_bungalow.first_occupant: Mr. G. R. Abreigh-Mackay, the first Principal of the Indore Residency College.
principals_bungalow.description: This building was constructed in 1878 and first occupied by Mr. G. R. Abreigh-Mackay.

indore_residency_school.title: The Indore Residency School
indore_residency_school.current_usage: Now occupied by the office of the Public Works Department.
indore_residency_school.historical_details: In the room facing the iron gate, a separate class for chiefs was conducted where they made their own arrangements for boarding and lodging.
indore_residency_school.teacher: Mr. G. Alberigh Mackay, tutor to the minor Raja of Ratlam.
indore_residency_school.origin_of_dc: This was the beginning of Daly College, then known as 'The Rajkumar Class'. In 1882 it became 'The Indore Residency Raj Kumar College' when the classes moved to the Old Boarding Houses.

old_boarding_houses.title: The Old Boarding Houses
old_boarding_houses.location: Site of the present K.E. Medical School.
old_boarding_houses.description: Constructed when the Rajkumar classes were separated from the Indore Residency School. The house contained about eight rooms, one of which was used as a reading room.

gwalior_boarding_house.title: The Gwalior Boarding House
notable_residents: H.H. Maharaja Tukoji Rao Puar of Dewas (Senior)
H.H. Raja Arun Singh of Narsinghgarh
H.H. Maharaja Tukoji Rao Holkar with his guardian Mr. Percy Hide

residence_periods.1898_1903: Residence of H.H. Maharaja Tukoji Rao Puar (Senior) and H.H. Raja Arun Singh.
residence_periods.1904: Occupied by H.H. Maharaja Tukoji Rao Holkar and Mr. Percy Hide; both participated in college games.

gwalior_boarding_house.usage_history: From 1905 to 1908 it accommodated about twenty Kumars with a housemaster.
gwalior_boarding_house.current_usage: Now used as the Chief's Guest House after several additions and alterations.

holkar_boarding_house.title: The Holkar Boarding House
holkar_boarding_house.description: Originally the building of the Indore Residency School, later used for Rajkumar classes before being moved to the Old Boarding Houses. This location marks the earliest foundation of what later became Daly College.
holkar_boarding_house.teacher: Mr. G. Alberigh Mackay, tutor to the minor Raja of Ratlam.

new_boarding_house.title: The New Boarding House
new_boarding_house.original_usage: Originally the college gymnasium, open on all sides.
new_boarding_house.converted_description: To provide accommodation for the Kumars, the gymnasium was walled and transformed into a boarding house with three large rooms, a bathroom, a housemaster's room, and a spacious south verandah.
new_boarding_house.surroundings: To the north were two tennis courts where European ladies and gentlemen often played tennis with the Kumars.

old_dc_playground.title: Old Daly College – Playground
old_dc_playground.description: A small plot to the west of the college building served as the only playground where the Kumars and staff played cricket, football, and hockey.

sports_history.1905: Mr. J.H. Smith, the Principal, inaugurated the C.I.S.A. sports association; its first meeting was held on this ground.
sports_history.1906: A separate football ground was created in the extreme north of the compound.

birth.family_background: His father, Francis Dermot Daly, served in British India from 1821 in the 4th Light Dragoons.

interests: Study of the States of the Malwa region

career.historical_role: A keen student of history and a highly respected British officer in India.
career.malwa_contribution: He gained trust and confidence of the Chiefs of the Malwa States.

legacy.educational_vision: His legacy to India was the creation of a modern British school system to educate the Princes of Central India.
institutions_founded: Several premier schools and colleges across the region through his leadership and influence
legacy.role_in_dc_creation: He initiated discussions and efforts that eventually led to the origin and development of Daly College.

daly_college_creation.reason_for_new_building: After several years in the Residency College building, it was felt a more substantial structure was needed to honour Sir Daly’s contribution.
daly_college_creation.funding: Magnanimous contributions flowed in from various rulers and supporters.
daly_college_creation.description: A majestic white marble structure named 'The Daly College' was constructed by the Public Works Department in 1906, at the center of a 118-acre campus.

final_years.injury: Towards the end of 1889, he suffered a serious injury in a fall while riding.

death.tribute: He is remembered as simple, unaffected and conscientious.
death.military_honour: Twice recommended for the Victoria Cross, the highest British military honour for gallantry.

birth.family_background: His father, Francis Dermot Daly, served in British India from 1821 in the 4th Light Dragoons.

traits: Highly respected by the Chiefs of the Malwa States

first_batch_daly_college.title: The College Coat of Arms
first_batch_daly_college.description: The Daly College Coat of Arms represents the main sections of the Central Indian community — Maratha, Rajput, Bundela, and Mohammedan. The arms were devised largely from those given to chiefs on the Delhi banners of 1877. All symbols are unified under the motto 'Gyanameva Shakti'.

first_quarter.name: Maratha & Shaivite (Holkar, Pawar, Scindia)

elements.colour: Tenne (nearest to Bhagwa — Maratha and Shaivite colour)
symbols: Wings — signify Pawar descent from the Parmars, associated with universal sovereignty.
Six bars argent and gules — Holkar banner.
Cobra — symbol of the Scindia house.

first_quarter.meaning: Represents the Maratha heritage and the Shaivite devotional colour, combining symbols of Pawars, Holkars, and Scindias.

second_quarter.name: Rajput Clans (Pachranga, Suryavanshi, Chandravanshi, Agnivanshi)

elements.colour: Barry of five (Pachranga — traditional Rajput five-colour banner)

second_quarter.meaning: Represents the major Rajput lineages that trace ancestry to the sun, moon, and fire.

third_quarter.name: Mohammedan States (Bhopal, Pindari, Sacred Emblems)

symbols: Tower — symbolizes Bhopal and the fort of Fatehgarh.
Spear and Talwar — Pindari martial elements.
Fish — sacred emblem known as 'Mani Martib'.

third_quarter.meaning: Symbolizes the Islamic heritage of Central India, including Bhopal and Pindari elements.

fourth_quarter.name: Bundela Clan (Bundelkhand, Vindhyas)

symbols: Chevron 'gutty de sang' — refers to the origin from 'bund', meaning a drop.
Fort on a hill — signifies Ath-kot of Bundelkhand and the Vindhya ranges.
Goddess Devi Vindhyvasini — the tutelary deity of the Bundela clan.

fourth_quarter.meaning: Represents Bundelkhand and its legendary origins, geography, and clan deity.

commemoration.reason: The College derives its name from him, and the Coat of Arms commemorates his legacy.

supporters.meaning: Together they represent the cultural and geographic unity of Central India.

first_batch_daly_college.description: The Padma Shri R. N. Zutshi Memorial Medal honours outstanding Old Dalians for excellence in diverse fields such as industry, business, management, public life, social service, diplomacy, defence, medicine, science, research, engineering, education, sports, arts, and media.

about_rn_zutshi.name: Padma Shri R. N. Zutshi
biography: Mr. R. N. Zutshi was the first Indian Principal of The Daly College.
He took charge in 1956 after serving the institution for 34 years.
Educated at St. John's School and St. John’s College, Agra.
Joined Daly College as Assistant Master in 1922.
Became Housemaster in 1943 and Headmaster in 1948.
Widely travelled to China, Japan, Malaya, Europe, and England.
Known for sportsmanship, great energy, and sense of humour.
public_work_and_contribution: Nominated member of the newly formed Municipal Corporation of Indore (1958).
Deputy Mayor of Indore (1960–1962) and Mayor (1963).
Served on the Government of India Merit Scholars selection panel (1957).
Played a role in the formation of the CBSE.
Advocated for a university in Indore; nominated to the University Court in 1964.
about_rn_zutshi.death: Passed away on the last day of term in April 1968.

medal_establishment.founded_by: Ms. Sulekha Zutshi (daughter of Padma Shri R. N. Zutshi)
medal_establishment.purpose: To honour Old Dalians who demonstrate exceptional achievement and contribution in any professional or public field.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Career Guidance Activities
first_batch_daly_college.description: Daly College conducts various career guidance activities, fairs, workshops, and seminars to expose students to global educational opportunities, industry insights, and future career pathways.

activities.title: Career Fair with 50 National and International Universities
activities.details: A large-scale Career Fair was organized at Daly College where 50 universities from India and abroad showcased their admission opportunities and career pathways.

sessions.speaker: Ms. Anjali Anand Seth, Regional Manager (South Asia), Huron University Canada
sessions.topic: Educational and Employment Opportunities in Canada

activities.title: Seminar – 'Be Future Ready'
activities.details: A seminar for parents and students of Classes 9–12 highlighting upcoming career opportunities, evolving job markets, and trends in higher education. Individual guidance was given to each student from Classes 9 and 11.

activities.title: Art and Design Workshop – De Montfort University, UK
activities.details: Professors from the Faculty of Arts and Design, De Montfort University (UK), including Mr. Jamie Scott and Mr. Gavin Kew conducted an art and design workshop.
activities.additional_notes: Old Dalian Disha Lulla, Student Ambassador for DMU, showcased her academic progress and guided students.
activities.outcome: Students explored new perspectives in art and design.

activities.title: Maths Workshop – University of Waterloo, Canada
activities.details: Professor Troy Vasiga from the University of Waterloo visited Daly College along with Ms. Seetha. He conducted an advanced mathematics workshop.
activities.target_group: Students of Classes XI and XII
activities.outcome: Students gained enriched mathematical insights and problem-solving exposure.

activities.title: Indian Universities Career Fair
activities.details: Daly College hosted a career fair featuring multiple Indian universities for both students and parents.

activities.title: Workshop – Basic Film Making for Social Good
activities.details: Students learned fundamentals of filmmaking including lighting, angles, and photography.
activities.participants: Dalians and students from other schools

activities.title: International Career Fair (UK, USA, Switzerland, Canada, Australia, Singapore)
activities.details: Daly College organized a career fair for students and parents of Classes X, XI, and XII, featuring universities from six countries.
activities.target_group: Students of Classes X, XI, XII and parents

activities.title: USA Universities Group Visit
activities.details: A delegation of U.S. universities visited Daly College. Students gained insights into U.S. higher education systems and emerging global careers.
activities.outcome: Students received updated information on international opportunities.

activities.title: DAAD Germany – Seminar by Mrs. Shubhada Choudhary
activities.details: Mrs. Shubhada Choudhary, Director of DAAD Mumbai, conducted a session on study and research opportunities in Germany.
activities.notes: Thanks to Mr. Avinash Kashyap and Mrs. Klaudia Kashyap for facilitating the session.

about_afs.name: AFS Intercultural Programs
about_afs.global_role: Provides intercultural learning opportunities and educational exchange programs.
highlights: One of the world’s largest community-based volunteer organisations.
Nearly 400,000 students, young adults and teachers have participated in AFS programs.
Since 1947, a similar number of host families have been part of AFS worldwide.
The core of all AFS programs is 'Stay and Study' in a different cultural setting.

core_ideas.stay_and_study: Participants live with a host family and study in a local school, experiencing a home and family life different from their own culture and routine.
core_ideas.youth_as_bridge_builders: AFS believes that today’s youth – and tomorrow’s leaders – are among the best bridge builders between nations.

volunteers.note: Volunteers keep the wheels of AFS running.

scale.target_age: Primarily 15–17.5 years for high school exchanges
scale.annual_opportunities: Thousands of high school-age students every year get the opportunity to live in another country for an academic year.
scale.impact: Participants learn to appreciate different cultures, break down barriers, and build profound lifelong relationships for themselves and their host families.

program_benefits.title: Program Benefits
benefits: Strong connection to and involvement with the people and way of life of the host country.
New relationships that change the participant’s outlook in profound ways.
Increased passion for understanding different cultures in addition to one’s own.
Ability to understand and express oneself in another language, often fluently.
A lifelong interest in and concern for other countries and international issues.
Greater flexibility when dealing with other people and unfamiliar situations.

program_details_overview.title: Intercultural Programs India – Overview
program_details_overview.description: AFS Intercultural Programs India provides intercultural learning opportunities to help people develop the knowledge, skills and understanding needed to create a more just and peaceful world.
history_and_presence: AFS has been running intercultural programs since 1947.
AFS is present in more than 54 countries.
Over 13,000 exchanges are conducted per year.
program_details_overview.essence: The essence of any AFS program is 'Stay and Study' in a different cultural setting, where participants live with a host family and attend a local school.
impact: Participants, host families, host schools and communities develop knowledge, skills and understanding for intercultural harmony.
AFS aims to build bridges of understanding and mutual respect between countries and cultures.
Programs focus on today’s youth as key bridge builders between nations.

initiatives_and_audience.aim: To strengthen AFS Intercultural Programs India’s presence among stakeholders through local and national initiatives and activities.
target_audience: Education and cultural exchange industry representatives
intercultural_education_focus: Advocating intercultural learning and cultural competencies.
Conducting workshops, seminars, talks and other events.
Helping individuals adapt and thrive in culturally varied environments.
initiatives_and_audience.overall_motive: To develop effectiveness in international environments, encourage cultural and personal self-understanding, and deepen learning from travel and life abroad through informal yet social, intercultural experiences.

afs_high_school_program.title: AFS High School Program
afs_high_school_program.description: A long-term academic exchange program for high school students to study and live abroad.
scale: Over the past five years, more than 500 high school students from India have gone abroad on AFS exchanges.
Destinations include the United States, Italy, Norway, Switzerland, Hong Kong, Japan, and many other countries.
Students can choose from over 52 AFS partner countries.

qualities: Awareness of Indian culture and global issues

class_exchange_program.title: Class Exchange Program
class_exchange_program.description: An exchange program between two schools, one from India and another from an AFS partner country, matched by type of school, age of students and language of communication.
group_structure: Groups can be formed by students from one or more classes.
If more than one class participates, students should have a common preparation in advance.
class_exchange_program.age_range: Preferably between 12 and 18 years, with exchanges between students of similar age.
class_exchange_program.time: Timings and exact period to be mutually discussed and agreed upon.

university_exchange_program.title: AFS University Exchange Program
university_exchange_program.description: A program that supports university-level exchanges, reaffirming the commitment to developing responsible global citizens.
key_points: Program content is flexible and varies from student to student.
Students can choose subjects from a wide range offered by the host university.
Focus is on deep intercultural immersion and academic enrichment.

community_service_exchange.title: AFS Community Service Exchange
community_service_exchange.description: An intercultural community service program for participants aged 18 and above.
aim: To help participants give back to the world through community service.
To develop awareness of surroundings and existing problems as global citizens.
scale: Programs run in more than 30 countries.
AFS India hosts around 10 students every year in this stream.
community_service_exchange.cost_note: Cost is similar to World Program fees.

exchange_program_for_teachers.title: Exchange Program for Teachers
exchange_program_for_teachers.description: A program for secondary school teachers who wish to experience teaching in another country and gain deep understanding of different educational systems.
eligibility: Teachers currently working in secondary schools.
The home school must support and take an active role in the program.
goals_for_participating_teacher: Experience teaching methods and school life in a different country.
Share teaching approaches with the entire staff in the host school.
Give pupils an intercultural experience by sharing their own culture.
collaborative_project: Two participating teachers (from sending and hosting countries) develop the project details together.
Expected to discuss details prior to the visits.
Conduct a joint evaluation and agree on follow-up activities at the end.
exchange_program_for_teachers.living_arrangement: The visiting teacher stays with a host family and experiences local teaching methods and community life.

hosting_overview.description: AFS India not only sends students abroad but also hosts students in India.
hosting_overview.scale: AFS India has hosted more than 100+ students from various countries who lived in Indian homes and attended local schools.

host_family_expectations.summary: AFS India host families provide a caring, structured, supportive environment.
responsibilities: Provide room and board for the exchange student.
Exercise general parental supervision similar to their own children.
Involve the student in daily household chores and activities.
afs_support: AFS India arranges school enrolment, tuition and other educational matters with the local secondary school (for long-term exchanges).
Program volunteers are devoted to the safety and well-being of the students.

cultural_showcase.description: AFS India provides a platform for hosted students from across the globe to display their cultural heritage.
activities: Showcasing food and artefacts from their home country.
Opportunities to virtually and physically experience different cultures coming together.
Talent-based activities to express pride in their nation before an audience.
cultural_showcase.aim: To celebrate cultural diversity, build intercultural understanding, and allow students to proudly represent their home country.

leadership_opportunities_for_returnees.title: Leadership Opportunity for Program Returnees
leadership_opportunities_for_returnees.description: AFS Intercultural Programs India offers internship and leadership opportunities to program returnees who are now in college and beginning their professional journey.
roles_and_exposure: Returnees act as facilitators for events under the guidance of a staff member from the national office.
The organizing committee gains hands-on experience in finance, logistics, communications and delegate servicing.

benefits_of_hosting_an_afs_participant.title: Benefits of Hosting an AFS Participant
benefits: Brings the family closer together through shared experiences.
Opens opportunities to meet community leaders through AFS activities.
Allows the family to see India and their own culture through new eyes.
Develops lifelong connections with the hosted participant and their family.
Increases knowledge, understanding and communication skills within the family.
Builds worldwide networks and friendships that last a lifetime.
Adds warmth and vibrancy to family life by creating an extended family.
Provides a fresh perspective on Indian culture while learning about the customs, ideas and values of another culture.
Enables families to make a positive, real contribution towards a more just and peaceful world through intercultural understanding.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Career Counselling & Guidance
first_batch_daly_college.description: The Career Counselling and Guidance Programme at Daly College helps students identify their strengths, talents, and interests to make informed decisions about subjects, careers, and higher education opportunities.
objectives: Identify students’ personality strengths, talents and interests.
Facilitate subject selection through informed decision-making.
Create awareness about diverse career opportunities.
Enable students to make choices aligned with current trends and future possibilities.
Support behavioural development through guidance and counselling.

curriculum_and_structure.overview: Daly College provides structured, methodical career counselling from Grade 7 to 12 based on a curated curriculum.
components: Career fairs with national and international universities

cialfo_integration.description: Daly College has partnered with Cialfo, a Singapore-based global ed-tech platform for career exploration and college application management.
cialfo_integration.access: Students from Grade 9 onwards use the Cialfo portal.
benefits: Researching new-age careers
Profile building
Essay and SOP writing support
Resume building
College search and comparison
Complete management of international and Indian college applications
cialfo_integration.support: Cialfo experts provide ongoing guidance and mentorship.

importance_of_counselling.statement: Career guidance and counselling play a vital role in the educational and personal development of students.
reasons: Students face varied personal problems and educational challenges.
Guidance helps shape personality, behaviour and decision-making.
Ensures balanced growth and maximum development of potential.

counsellors_role.description: Career counsellors at Daly College support students in navigating academic and career development pathways.
roles: Assist in subject and career planning.
Guide students through the college admissions process.
Help students explore career fields through curated sessions.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Student Counselling at The Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: Daly College provides confidential and professional student counselling services to support emotional wellbeing, personal growth, and effective resolution of personal difficulties. Counselling is available to students, parents, and caregivers free of charge.

introduction.overview: Student Counselling at Daly College offers confidential support for students and parents. The aim is to help individuals cope more effectively with personal or emotional difficulties.
benefits: Provides a private and safe space to discuss concerns.
Offers a new, professional perspective on problems.
Supports emotional wellbeing and behavioural development.
counsellor_profile: Highly qualified with advanced degrees from top institutions.
Many years of experience working with students and adults.
Well-versed in the latest international research and developments in counselling.

points.explanation: Counselling offers a private space to explore personal issues with someone who has no direct role in the individual's life. While not an instant cure, it helps clarify problems and offer fresh perspectives.
Counsellors are trained to be non-judgmental, objective, and respectful. They offer psychological space that friends or family may not be able to provide.
No issue is too big or too small. Early counselling prevents small concerns from growing into major emotional problems.
Talking to a neutral person itself is therapeutic and helps relieve internal stress.

why_counselling_works.summary: Any concern—big or small—can be discussed in counselling.

how_counselling_works.description: The goal of counselling is to listen to an individual’s personal and emotional concerns to provide support and clarity.
principles: Counsellors do not give advice; they help clients make their own decisions.
Moral judgments or directives are never imposed.
Suggestions may be offered based on training and experience.
Clients are free to accept or reject suggestions.

misconceptions.clarification: Counsellors never judge clients. Emotional difficulties often arise due to stress, confusion, or mental distress—not personal failure. Judgement is counterproductive and never part of counselling.
Asking for help is a sign of strength. Great individuals have sought support at difficult times. Counselling reduces stress and helps people return to their chosen path in life.

duration.summary: Counselling duration varies depending on individual needs.
details: Some students need only one session.
Others return for multiple sessions over time.
Each individual's situation is unique and supported accordingly.

issues_addressed.description: The counselling team has helped numerous students and parents manage emotional and behavioural challenges.
issues_addressed.note: Counselling also helps individuals who simply feel confused or unhappy without any specific identifiable issue.

confidentiality.statement: Counselling at Daly College adheres to strict professional standards and ethics.
rules: No information is shared without the client's consent.
Confidentiality is broken only if there is clear evidence of severe risk to self or others.
Counselling aims to build self-esteem and emotional strength.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Special Education Needs Department – FOCUS
first_batch_daly_college.description: FOCUS, the Special Education Needs Department of Daly College, was established in 2011 with the mission of looking beyond weaknesses and nurturing every child’s unique strengths so they can reach their maximum potential.

philosophy.statement: Every child matters at Daly College.
principles: Belief that some children require additional support to succeed.
Commitment to educating and empowering students in a non-segregated environment.
Individualised instruction tailored to each child's needs.

approach.sensitivity_and_support: The SEN Department is sensitive to the needs of children requiring special educational support and strives to serve their diverse developmental and academic needs.
approach.mainstreaming_process: Learners with special needs are steadily mainstreamed from junior classes to senior school through structured remedial interventions, accommodations and modifications aligned with CBSE guidelines.
approach.focus_on_strengths: The department emphasizes strengths-based education, allowing each child to experience meaningful progress and independence.

support_areas.title: Support Areas
areas: Classrooms – Sensitising peers and staff, extending support to children with special needs (CWSN).
The Resource Room 'FOCUS' – A dedicated space for specialised learning support.
Intensive remedial instruction based on Individualised Education Plans (IEPs).
Occupational Therapy – Supporting sensory, motor and functional skill development.
Shadow Teachers – Providing personalised classroom assistance when required.
Parent Partnership – Collaborative support system involving regular communication and guidance.
Our Team – A multidisciplinary group offering professional expertise.

team.volunteers: Old students of Daly College who contribute to the SEN support system.

first_batch_daly_college.title: House System – Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: The House System at Daly College fosters teamwork, discipline, identity, and healthy competition. Students belong to Houses for Inter-House competitions while residing in age-specific buildings.

houses.inter_house_competitions: All Inter-House competitions at Daly College are conducted among these Houses.

age_specific_residences.note: Students belong to their Houses for competitions but live in age-specific residences for boarding.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Sports at Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: Daly College provides a wide range of sports facilities and opportunities, promoting physical fitness, discipline, teamwork, and excellence across multiple disciplines.

additional_facilities.gymnastics: The school is actively working to regain its historic excellence in gymnastics.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Performing Arts at Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: Daly College nurtures creativity and artistic expression through a rich Performing Arts programme that includes dance, dramatics, music and instrumental training. Students gain confidence, teamwork skills and stage experience through inter-house, inter-school and IPSC competitions.

dance.title: Dance
dance.overview: The school provides excellent facilities and specialised faculty for developing dance skills.
highlights: Choreography is one of the most awaited competitions on campus.
Students have delivered exceptional performances at IPSC competitions over the past eleven years.
Boys and girls participate enthusiastically across all dance forms.

english_dramatics.title: English Dramatics
english_dramatics.overview: English dramatics allows students to explore acting, direction, and stagecraft in the English language.
details: Students receive guidance during Inter-Public School competitions and Annual Prize Giving productions.
For inter-house competitions, students independently manage scripting, editing, directing and staging the play.
Promotes leadership, creativity, teamwork and confidence.

hindi_dramatics.title: Hindi Dramatics
hindi_dramatics.overview: A long-standing cultural hobby ranging from mythological plays to light comedies.
details: Students handle scripting, direction and production at the house level.
Participants have consistently excelled in IPSC competitions with an enviable record.
Promotes appreciation of Indian literature and theatrical tradition.

indian_music.title: Indian Music
indian_music.overview: Students receive guidance for Inter-Public School competitions and Annual Prize Giving musical productions.
details: For inter-house events, students take charge of scripting, editing and production.
Encourages students to explore classical and semi-classical Indian music traditions.

english_solo.title: English Solo Singing
english_solo.overview: A platform for students to develop vocal skills in Western and English-language music.
details: Encourages confidence, stage presence and musical expression.
Promotes solo vocal excellence through competitions and performances.

western_music.title: Western Music
western_music.overview: A very popular hobby among students, covering both vocal and instrumental training.
details: Training offered in vocal and instrumental music.
School encourages formation of student-led bands.
Supports modern genres, contemporary music and performance skills.

school_band.title: School Brass Band
school_band.overview: The brass band is a growing and vibrant activity at Daly College.
school_band.size: Over 50 boys and girls currently participate.
highlights: Plays an important role in National festival celebrations.
Includes students from both Senior and Junior School.
Operates under the guidance of a trained instructor.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Visual Arts at Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: The Visual Arts Department at Daly College nurtures creativity, imagination, craftsmanship and technical skill through a wide spectrum of art-based hobbies, workshops and exhibition opportunities.

fine_arts.title: Fine Arts
fine_arts.overview: Students receive expert training to develop artistic skills across multiple creative categories.

sculpture_and_pottery.title: Sculpture and Pottery
sculpture_and_pottery.overview: A fully equipped sculpture and pottery section with a functioning kiln supports 3D creativity and craftsmanship.
highlights: Regular student work is showcased in the Annual Exhibitions.
Art pieces are displayed across the campus to enhance aesthetic appeal.

woodcraft.title: Woodcraft
woodcraft.overview: A traditional and highly creative hobby that develops craftsmanship and artistic design.
details: Students work independently at the house level.
Projects range from decorative pieces to functional wooden items.
Students have shown outstanding performance in IPSC competitions.

photography.title: Photography
photography.overview: Photography has evolved into a dynamic and expressive hobby at Daly College.
details: Students produce still photographs as well as video recordings of major events.
Best works are showcased in APG Exhibitions.
Selected photographs form part of the school’s Annual Exhibitions.

electronics.title: Electronics

computer_skills.title: Computer Skills

bamboo_craft.title: Bamboo Craft

skills: Creating decorative and functional bamboo items

needle_work.title: Needle Work

first_batch_daly_college.title: Model United Nations (MUN) – Daly College
first_batch_daly_college.description: Model United Nations at Daly College nurtures diplomacy, critical thinking, debate and international awareness through conferences, crisis sessions, inter-school participation and dedicated MUN Club activities.

overview.summary: MUN at Daly College has always been a rewarding opportunity for students, enabling them to learn diplomacy, negotiation and global problem-solving.
highlights: Develops leadership, research and public speaking skills.
Promotes global citizenship and awareness of international affairs.
Encourages collaboration, teamwork and crisis-solving.

dcm_un_2022.title: DCMUN 2022
dcm_un_2022.chief_guest_opening: Rtn. Amb. Mr. Anil Trigunayat (Distinguished IFS Officer)
dcm_un_2022.theme: Yuemanzekui – 'The moon waxes only to wane' (based on Chinese philosophy)
dcm_un_2022.scenario_presented: A hypothetical dissolution of the People’s Republic of China, focusing on socio-economic aspects.
dcm_un_2022.participating_schools: 15 schools across India and the Gulf region
student_experience: Displayed remarkable enthusiasm and strong debating skills.
Engaged in meaningful discussion around geopolitical crises.
Presented resolutions and arguments across diverse agendas.

midnight_crisis.description: A special crisis-session held at midnight to enhance critical thinking and crisis-resolution capabilities.

dcm_un_2022.chief_guest_closing: Mr. Salman Khurshid, Hon. Ex Cabinet Minister of External Affairs, senior advocate and author
dcm_un_2022.outcome: DCMUN 2022 concluded with enhanced collaboration, global awareness, and confident diplomacy skills among participants.

external_mun_participation.description: Dalians enthusiastically participated in several Inter-school MUNs throughout the year.
external_mun_participation.achievements: Students won multiple laurels for their outstanding performance and returned with strengthened global perspectives.

indore_world_summit_mun.title: Indore World Summit MUN 2022
indore_world_summit_mun.description: One of India’s largest high school leadership conferences.
highlights: Students showcased exceptional leadership, diplomacy and debate skills.
Numerous awards were won by Dalians across various committees.

mun_club.title: MUN Club at Daly College
mun_club.purpose: To nurture MUNers from a young age, teaching the fundamentals of diplomacy, debate and committee procedures.
activities: Weekly mock sessions and debates every Saturday.
Training on research, moderated caucuses, unmoderated caucuses and resolution writing.
Workshops on international relations and diplomacy.
intra_school_events: Inter-house MUN for classes 6 to 12, providing a competitive platform for student delegates.
mun_club.vision: To continue deliberating on pressing global issues and help students evaluate and analyze complex international situations.

overall_impact.statement: Model United Nations at Daly College has successfully nurtured confident young leaders who are globally aware and ready to take action.
overall_impact.conclusion: The MUN programme remains a roaring success, inspiring global awareness and leadership in students each year.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Co-Curricular Activities – Literary Societies
first_batch_daly_college.description: Daly College promotes language proficiency, public speaking, and literary appreciation through its English and Hindi Literary Societies. Multiple competitions are held at Inter-House, Inter-School, IPSC and National levels.

english_literary_society.title: English Literary Society (ELS)
english_literary_society.selection_process: Students are selected based on their school performance and trained to participate in IPSC and national competitions.

hindi_literary_society.title: Hindi Literary Society
hindi_literary_society.selection_process: Students demonstrating excellence at the school level are chosen to represent Daly College in IPSC and National literary events.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Technocrats Club
first_batch_daly_college.description: The Technocrats Club at Daly College nurtures creativity, technological awareness and hands-on learning in the field of computer science, electronics and emerging technologies. It exposes students to the latest advancements and provides opportunities for innovation, research and collaboration.
first_batch_daly_college.vision: To expose students to advancements in computer technology and foster creativity, innovation and technical excellence.
objectives: Provide computer and device-based knowledge with mentored training.
Nurture creative thinking and guide students toward high-quality research in computer technology.
Offer application-based examples to help students translate theory into practical work.
Provide a forum for open discussion on public-interest matters related to technology.
Enhance students’ professional development and networking opportunities with technical experts.

activities_current_year.title: Activities & Tasks Conducted During the Year

visits.title: Visit to Acropolis College of Engineering
visits.details: A collaborative visit for students from Technocrats, Entrepreneurship, and Social Service League clubs.
purpose: Visits to multiple labs to gain technical insights.
Interaction with the Social Entrepreneurship Cell to understand cost-effective sanitary pad manufacturing.

visits.title: Visit to IIT Indore – Big Data & Artificial Intelligence Lectures (August 27, 2019)
visits.participants: Science students of Classes 11–12, Motor Mechanics Club, Entrepreneurship Club, staff members
visits.campus_overview: 500-acre campus with advanced laboratories, libraries and research centres.
visit_highlights: Interaction with Professors of Computer Science and Space Engineering.
Visits to Chemistry and Biosciences labs.
Tour of the HELIUM building library.
Visit to the HYDROGEN building’s sophisticated instrumentation center.
Viewing electron microscope images including a pollen grain sample.
Tour of Physics and Engineering labs in the MANGANESE building, including glass blowing demonstrations.
Lectures on Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Big Data, Astronomy and Astrophysics.
visits.note: Daly College aims to maintain long-term collaboration with IIT Indore.

first_batch_daly_college.title: Subject Exhibition at Annual Prize Giving (APG)
first_batch_daly_college.description: During the Annual Prize Giving (APG), multiple academic and hobby departments of Daly College showcase subject-based exhibitions, reflecting the creativity, knowledge and skills of students across disciplines.

exhibition_details.english_literary_society: The English Literary Society contributes to APG through its literary exhibitions and displays.

hobby_departments.description: All hobby departments from the Still Arts section compulsorily put up exhibitions during APG.
hobby_departments.note: These exhibitions include creative, artistic and project-based displays showcasing student talent.
